65.heading: La Folie du Sacre-Coeur. English.
65.title: Madwoman of the Sacred Heart
65.author: story by Alexandro Jodorowsky; art by Jean "Moebius" Giraud ; letters by Dave Cooper ; translated by Randy and Jean-Marc Lofficier.
notes: 1 v. : ill. ; 22 cm.
Translation of: Le Coeur Couronné 1: La Folie du Sacre-Coeur.

Summary: "In a world of narco-terrorism, fifty-second soundbites, and multi-national corporations, how would we deal with a new Savior? Would we, like the Romans, even be aware of the birth of a new Messiah? Could we tell the difference between John the Baptist and just another sect of nuts?"

99.heading: Folklore.
99.title: Anno's Italy
99.author: Mitsumasa Anno.
notes: Japanese edition entitled My journey II, which is a translation of Tabi no ehon, II.
Summary: A pictorial presentation of rural, town, and city scenes in Italy, which contain hidden images from fine arts, religion, history, and folklore.
Genres: Stories without words, puzzles.

100.heading: Folklore.
100.title: Anno's Journey
100.author: Mitsumasa Anno.
notes: Published in 1977 under title: My journey, which is a translation of Tabi no ehon.
Summary: Records in drawings the author's journey through northern Europe and his impressions of the land, the people at work and play, and their art, architecture, folklore, and fairy tales.
Narrative without words.

106.title: Folklore and the Comic Book : the traditional meets the popular
106.author: Amanda Carson Banks, Elizabeth E
notes: 11 leaves : ill. ; 28 cm.
Printed with permission on Jan. 4, 1999 from Newfolklore: The Impromptu Journal, issue 2 (Jan. 1998).

Summary: A discussion of traditional folkloric archetypes used to creative effect in contemporary comic books Hellblazer, Swamp Thing, and Sandman.

109.heading: Folkman, David, 1946-
109.title: "Almost Famous : Hogan's Alley Surveys the Best Comic Strips You Might Not Be Reading"
109.author: written by David Folkman, Nat Gertler, Tom Heintjes and Peter Wallace
109.appears_in: p. 54-70 in Hogan's Alley, no. 10 (=v. 3, no. 2) (Summer 2002).
notes: Description and samples of "Betty" (Gary Delainey and Gerry Rasmussen) p. 55 ; "Between Friends" (Sandra Bell-Lundy), p. 55-56 ; "The Big Picture" (Lennie Peterson) p. 56 ; "Captain Ribman" (Rich Davis & John Sprengelmeyer) p. 56 ; "Castles in the Sand" (Henrik Rehr) p. 57 ; "Cats with Hands" (Joe Martin) p. 57-59 ; "The Dinette Set" (Julie Larson) p. 59-60 ; "Edge City" (Terry & Patty LaBan) p. 60-61 ; "Frazz" (Jef Mallett) p. 61 ; "Maakies" (Tony Millionaire) p. 61-62 ; "Natural Selection" (Russ Wallace) p. 62 ; "9 Chickweed Lane" (Brooke McEldowney) p. 62-63 ; "The Norm" (Michael Jantze) p. 63-64 ; "The Other Coast" (Adrian Raeside) p. 64 ; "Pooch Cafe" (Paul Gilligan) p. 64-65 ; "Preteena" (Allison Barrows) p. 65 ; "Raising Duncan" (Chris Browne) p. 66 ; "Red and Rover" (Brian Bassett) p. 66-67 ; "Rhymes with Orange" (Hilary B. Price) p. 67 ; "Sea Urchins" (Scott Eckelaert and Jason Whitley) p. 67-68 ; "Shirley and Son" (Jerry Bittle) p. 68-69 ; "Soup to Nutz" (Rick Stromoski) p. 69 ; "Tom the Dancing Bug" (Ruben Bolling) p. 69-70 ; "Wildwood" (Tom Spurgeon & Dan Wright) p. 70.

110.heading: Folkman, David, 1946-
110.title: "Flashback"
110.author: David Folkman
110.appears_in: p. 12 in Hogan's Alley, no. 9 (=v. 3, no. 1) (Summer 2001).
notes: Folkman surveyed cartoonists in 1967, asking about the importance of art education to the career. Terse responses from Charles Schulz, Hal Foster, Mort Walker, Milton Caniff, Zack Mosley, Chic Young, Lank Leonard, Ed Dodd, Irv Phillips, Walter Berndt, Don Tobin, Al Smith, and Bud Sagendorf.

111.heading: Folkman, David, 1946-
111.title: "Flashback"
111.author: David Folkman
111.appears_in: p. 12 in Hogan's Alley, no. 10 (=v. 3, no. 2) (Summer 2002).
notes: A survey question, "How did you first come up with the idea for your strip, and how much preliminary research did you do before attempting to start it?" is answered briefly by Hal Foster, Ernie Bushmiller, Charles M. Schulz, Otto Soglow, Mort Walker, Chic Young, Milton Caniff, Bud Sagendorf, Lank Leonard, Ed Dodd, and Irv Philipps.

123.heading: Folks.
123.title: "Cowardice Revisited" 8 p. in Ghostly Tales, no. 84
123.author: [No author]
notes: Art signed: PAIII.

Summary: A young woman is cooking in a deserted Southern mansion. A motorcycle gang called Satan's Angels decides to tear up the house and begins threatening her. A civil war soldier comes back to life to rescue her. The mansion burns down. She invites the resurrected and redeemed former coward to her house to meet her folks.

126.heading: Folks.
126.title: "I Just Don't Know, Harold"
126.author: Art Sansom.
notes: Summary: One of the long-haired teenagers on the beach asks the other why her folks don't like him.

127.heading: Folks.
127.title: "I Told Them It Was Educational"
127.author: by Irwin Hasen.
notes: Summary: Grandma McGowan meets Dondi at Kennedy Airport, and Dondi wonders why his folks let him come to New York; meanwhile two suspicious types are observing them.

128.heading: Folks.
128.title: "She Would Clean House"
128.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Martha reads the Major's essay, and speaks of the patriotism of her folks, the one-shot Rathbuns of Kentucky; he wishes she could be smuggled into the Kremlin with a mop.
Key words: Russia, courage, tigresses, typewriters.

129.heading: Folks.
129.title: "The Tree Folk"
129.author: Gardner Fox, script ; Jack Lehti, art
notes: Appearance of Deela ; the Tree Folk are the villains, introduced here.
Data from Bob Cherry, Gene Reed, Lou Mougin, et al., via Grand Comics Database Project.

131.title: "Folkways Demonstrations"
